properties.Name: BillOfLading
properties.Description:
The Bill of Lading acts as evidence of a contract of carriage between the shipper and the shipping line to carry out the transportation of cargo under the terms and conditions agreed upon between the seller and buyer. 

It proves the existence of a goods transportation contract.

- RECEIPT OF THE GOODS.
The BOL is issued by the carrier to the shipper in exchange for the receipt of the cargo. This is proof that the carrier has received the goods from the shipper in apparently good condition.

- EVIDENCE OF THE CONTRACT BETWEEN CARRIER AND SHIPPER.
As evidence of a contract, a BOL is the contract of carriage between the carrier and shipper in order to transport the freight.

- DOCUMENT OF TITLE TO THE GOODS. 
A document of title means the freight can be transferred to the holder of the BOL. Now, the holder of the BOL has the right to claim to transfer the goods to another.

Bill of Lading is one of the three crucial documents which is used excessively in international trade to ensure the exporters receive their payment and respective importers receive their merchandise. The other two important documents in international trade would be the policy of insurance and an invoice.

Columns.Name: ShipmentId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipment.

Columns.Name: DocumentId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Document.

Columns.Name: ShipperName
Columns.Description: The name of the Shipper.

Columns.Name: ShipperNumber
Columns.Description: The number assigned to the Shipper by the US Government.

Columns.Name: ShipFromLocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a location.

Columns.Name: ShipFromDate
Columns.Description: The date of the shipment.

Columns.Name: ConsigneeName
Columns.Description: The name of the Consignee.

Columns.Name: ConsigneeAddress
Columns.Description: The 'street/po box' component of the Consignee address.

Columns.Name: ConsigneeCity
Columns.Description: The 'city' component of the Consignee address.

Columns.Name: ConsigneeStateProvince
Columns.Description: The 'state/province' component of the Consignee address.

Columns.Name: ConsigneeCountry
Columns.Description: The 'country' component of the Consignee address.

Columns.Name: ShipmentDestinationAddress
Columns.Description: The 'street/po box' component of the Shipment address.

Columns.Name: ShipmentDestinationCity
Columns.Description: The 'city' component of the Shipment address.

Columns.Name: ShipmentDestinationCountry
Columns.Description: The 'country' component of the Shipment address.

Columns.Name: PrepaidChargedIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that charges are to be prepaid.

Columns.Name: NonNegotiableBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description:
Non-negotiable bills of lading are bills of lading that, due to their nature, cannot be transferred to a third party. 

These non-negotiable documents came into being out of necessity to create a document that did not have to be presented to the master at destination. 

The goods are delivered to the named consignee in the document who only has to prove his identity.

Columns.Name: AmountToBeAppliedToCharges
Columns.Description: An amount paid that is to be applied to charges.

Columns.Name: CodShipmentIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Shipment is COD.

Columns.Name: CodCollectionFee
Columns.Description: The collection fee for the COD shipment.

Columns.Name: TotalCodChargesAmount
Columns.Description: The total COD charges amount.

Columns.Name: ShipperAgentId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the Shipper Agent.

Columns.Name: CarrierId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Carrier.

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Bill Of Lading Type.

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingCreatedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp when the bill of lading was created.

Columns.Name: NegotiableBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description:
Negotiable bills of lading are bills of lading which can be transferred to a third party by endorsement.

The bill of lading must meet the following two conditions:

- it must be drawn up to order or to bearer
- it has to be clean.

It follows that bills of lading to a named person and bills of lading with restrictive clauses (with regard to the quantity and the condition of the goods) are not negotiable.

In case of a bill of lading to a named person, only the consignee on who's name the bill of lading was made out, has the right to receive the goods.

Columns.Name: NumberOfDaysAfterShipmentPresentationMustBeMade
Columns.Description:
The number of days in which presentation must be made in compliance with the terms and conditions of the credit. 

If no such period of time is stipulated, banks will not accept documents presented to them later than 21 days after the date of Shipment. In any event, documents must be presented not later than the expiry date of the credit.

Columns.Name: ConsigneePostalCode
Columns.Description: The 'zip code/postal code' component of the Consignee address.

Columns.Name: ShipmentDestinationState
Columns.Description: The 'state/province' component of the shipment final delivery address.

Columns.Name: ShipmentDestinationPostalCode
Columns.Description: The 'zip code/postal code' component of the shipment final delivery address.

Columns.Name: MaximumCarrierDeliveryChargeAmount
Columns.Description: If the carrier is collecting payment upon delivery, the bill of lading must include both the maximum amount the carrier will charge to deliver the shipment

Columns.Name: GuaranteedPickupTimestamp
Columns.Description: The guaranteed pickup date of the shipment items if a guaranteed service.

Columns.Name: ActualPickupTimestamp
Columns.Description: The actual pickup date of the shipment items.

Columns.Name: DeclaredShipmentValueAmount
Columns.Description: The declared value of the shipment.

Columns.Name: StaleBillOfLadingTimestamp
Columns.Description:
The timestamp when the bill of lading is determined to be 'stale'.

Stale Bill of Lading
Every credit which calls for a transport document(s) should also stipulate a specified period of time after the date of Shipment, during which presentation must be made in compliance with the terms and conditions of the credit. If no such period of time is stipulated, banks will not accept documents presented to them later than 21 days after the date of Shipment. In any event, documents must be presented not later than the expiry date of the credit.

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingPaymentMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a bill of lading payment method.

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingMediaFormatId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a bill of lading media format.

Columns.Name: NonBindingCarrierCostToShipGoodsAmount
Columns.Description: The non-binding estimate of carrier costs to ship the goods.

Columns.Name: NumberOfShippingUnits
Columns.Description: The number of shipping units associated with the bill of lading.

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the bill of lading.

Columns.Name: SwitchBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description:
Shippers use this type in foreign-to-foreign shipments to keep suppliers and consignee information confidential.

A second set of Bill of Lading issued by the carrier (or its agent) to substitute the original bills of lading issued at the time of shipment. 

The information on a Switch B/L is not meant to be identical to the original B/L it substitutes.

The switch Bill of Lading format is exactly the same as the original's and it deals with the same cargo. It holds the same value and purpose as an original Bill of Lading:

- Evidence of contract of carriage A receipt for goods
- Title to the goods

Columns.Name: ReleaseViaTelegraphicTransferIndicator
Columns.Description:
A telex release is typically delivered by email and incurs additional expenses. 

Ideally, a telex release is quick and convenient, but issues with paperwork can cause delays and may increase costs. 

It is not a replacement for a bill of lading. Instead, a telex release is a convenient option for shippers who do not need original documents for their accounting or legal records.

In some cases, a telex release may be requested because of a problem with the original bill of lading. If the documents are lost, stolen or otherwise inaccessible, the shipper must request a telex release from the shipping company. 

This process is generally quite time-consuming and often results in additional charges for freight storage. The carrier sends the telex release when the original bill of lading is located or when a letter of indemnity from the shipper is provided.

Columns.Name: PickupInstructions
Columns.Description:
Instructions related to the pickup of the shipment.

Ex:
- Place of pickup
- Forwarding agent contacts and references
- Carrier pre-carriage details
- Consolidation center details

Columns.Name: DeliveryInstructions
Columns.Description:
Instructions related to the delivery of the shipment.

Ex:
- Point of final delivery for the goods
- Delivery agent details
- Consolidation center details

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingReleaseMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a bill of lading release method.

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingClosedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the bill of lading was closed.

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingIssuedToCarrierTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the bill of lading was issued to the carrier.

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingReceivedByCarrierTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp when the bill of lading was received by the carrier.

Columns.Name: ShipperAddress
Columns.Description: The 'street/po box' component of the shipper.

Columns.Name: ShipperCity
Columns.Description: The 'city' component of the shipper.

Columns.Name: ShipperState
Columns.Description: The 'state' component of the shipper.

Columns.Name: ShipperPostalCode
Columns.Description: The 'postal code' component of the shipper.

Columns.Name: ShipperCountry
Columns.Description: The 'country' component of the shipper.

Columns.Name: ShipmentLoadedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp when the shipment is loaded.

Columns.Name: ShipmentReceivedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp when the shipment is received.

Columns.Name: ShipmentTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp when the shipment is initiated.

Columns.Name: CargoDescription
Columns.Description: A description of the cargo associated with the bill of lading.

Columns.Name: MasterBillOfLadingIndictor
Columns.Description:
Issued by the shipping carrier to freight forwarder/NVOCC, who is listed as the shipper, consignee, and notify party.

If you've booked your shipment through an intermediary, there will be two sets of Bills of Lading involved in the shipment. These are known as the master Bill of Lading and the house Bill of Lading.

Columns.Name: HouseBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description:
Issued by the NVOCC or freight forwarder to the actual exporter of the merchandise.

If you've booked your shipment through an intermediary, there will be two sets of Bills of Lading involved in the shipment. These are known as the master Bill of Lading and the house Bill of Lading.

Columns.Name: OriginalBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description: Issued in sets of originals (usually three). One of the original needs to be presented at destination to secure release of cargo.

Columns.Name: TelexReleaseBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description:
A virtual copy of the Original Bill of Lading. 

A copy can be presented to secure the release of cargo at destination.

A Telex Release is a digital version of the original Bill of Lading that allows merchandise to be released without needing to produce a physical copy of the original Bill of Lading.

Hard copies of the original Bill of Lading are still issued and the Telex Release is by no means a substitute. However, by presenting a digital copy in the form of a Telex Release is enough to secure the release of the cargo.

With a Telex Release, the shipper holds on to the set of original Bill of Ladings. 

There is no need for the shipper to send the originals to the importer. As soon as the shipper gets paid, he sends the set of original Bill of Ladings to the carrier and requests for a Telex Release, with which the buyer or consignee can receive the cargo at destination.

The Telex Release offers three main advantages:

- It's fast and convenient.
- It expedites the customs clearance process.
- It eliminates

Columns.Name: ExpressBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description:
No original hard copy of the Bill of Lading involved. 

It is usually issued in cases whereby the shipper and consignee are part of the same company and no negotiations are required.

Columns.Name: ShipmentRoutingInstructions
Columns.Description: Instructions related to the routing of the shipment.

Columns.Name: BookingNumber
Columns.Description: A unique control number to reference the shipment with the carrier.

Columns.Name: ThroughBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description:
A through B/L is almost similar to Combined Transport B/L with the exception that the carrier is directly liable for the port to port transportation of the shipment.

However, for the non-coastal inland movement, the carrier performs the role of an agent by arranging the transportation. In this case, the carrier is supposed to specify the terms on the through B/L.

In a Through B/L, the sections like "Pre-Carriage by", On-Carriage by" etc. will be entered. Many people have a false notion as they term a bill as Telex Release B/L when there is no such term in existence.

Columns.Name: InlandBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description:
Inland bills of lading are often the first transportation document issued for the international shipment. 

They are used for cargo shipments by rail or road, but not sea.

Columns.Name: CombinedTransportBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description:
The combined bill of lading will cover whatever means or modes of transport have been used to carry out the shipment from origin to destination. 

A single contract will encompass all of the services and transportation carried out to deliver the goods.

Columns.Name: DirectBillOfLadingIndicator
Columns.Description: When the vessel is used to pick up the cargo and goods are delivered to the final destination.

Columns.Name: PrepaidShippingAmount
Columns.Description:
The amount that has been prepaid by the shipper. 
This is usually the ocean freight price and any extra charges at origin.

Columns.Name: CargoCollectionAmountDue
Columns.Description: The amount that needs to be paid for cargo collection. This can be the ocean freight price if it hasn't been prepaid, as well as the DTHC charges and other local charges that apply.

Columns.Name: BillOfLadingMovementTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a bill of lading movement type.

Columns.Name: ShipperEmailAddress
Columns.Description: The shipper's email address.

Columns.Name: ShipperTelephoneNumber
Columns.Description: The shipper's telephone number.

Columns.Name: ConsigneeEmailAddress
Columns.Description: The consignees email address.

Columns.Name: ConsigneeTelephoneNumber
Columns.Description: The consignees telephone number.

Columns.Name: GrossShipmentWeightUnits
Columns.Description: The gross weight of the shipment.

Columns.Name: WeightUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ShipperAccountNumber
Columns.Description: The account number of the shipper.

Columns.Name: ShipperSignature
Columns.Description: The shipper's signature.

Columns.Name: ShipperSignatureLocationName
Columns.Description: The name of the place of the shipper's signature.

Columns.Name: DeclaredValueToCarriageAmount
Columns.Description: The declared value limits the liability of carrier in case of loss, damage to cargo and the valuation charges are assessed on the amount of declared value.

Columns.Name: DeclaredValueForCustomerAmount
Columns.Description: The declared value for customs usage.

Columns.Name: PrepaidFreightAmount
Columns.Description: The amount that was prepaid for freight.

Columns.Name: TotalCollectChargesDueAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of collect charges due regarding the bill of lading,

Columns.Name: ShippingCustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Columns.Name: FromShippingLocationTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the shipment departs the from-shipping location.

Columns.Name: ToShippingLocationTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the shipment arrives at the ship-to location.

Columns.Name: ShipToLocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipping Location.

Columns.Name: LocationOfInitialReceiptId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipping Location.

Columns.Name: FreightPayableLocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipping Location.

Columns.Name: HazardSeverityCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Hazard Severity Category.

Columns.Name: ShipperPartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: ReceiptOfGoodsShippingLocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipping Location.

Columns.Name: ConsigneePartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: ReceivingCustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Properties.Description:
The Bill of Lading acts as evidence of a contract of carriage between the shipper and the shipping line to carry out the transportation of cargo under the terms and conditions agreed upon between the seller and buyer. 

It proves the existence of a goods transportation contract.

- RECEIPT OF THE GOODS.
The BOL is issued by the carrier to the shipper in exchange for the receipt of the cargo. This is proof that the carrier has received the goods from the shipper in apparently good condition.

- EVIDENCE OF THE CONTRACT BETWEEN CARRIER AND SHIPPER.
As evidence of a contract, a BOL is the contract of carriage between the carrier and shipper in order to transport the freight.

- DOCUMENT OF TITLE TO THE GOODS. 
A document of title means the freight can be transferred to the holder of the BOL. Now, the holder of the BOL has the right to claim to transfer the goods to another.

Bill of Lading is one of the three crucial documents which is used excessively in international trade to ensure the exporters receive their payment and respective importers receive their merchandise. The other two important documents in international trade would be the policy of insurance and an invoice.
